revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} '''Afropolitan''' is a term constructed from the name ''[[Africa]]'' and the [[ancient Greek]] word ''πολίτης'' ('politis'), meaning 'citizen' (itself from ''polis'', 'city').<ref>"-polis, comb. form." ''OED Online'', Oxford University Press, January 2018, www.oed.com/view/Entry/146861. Accessed 23 January 2018. "cosmopolitan, adj. and n." ''OED Online'', Oxford University Press, January 2018, www.oed.com/view/Entry/42259. Accessed 23 January 2018.</ref> It is an attempt at redefining African phenomena by placing emphasis on ordinary citizens' experiences in Africa. ''Afropolitanism'' is similar to the older [[Pan-Africanism|Panafricanism]] ideology. However, it defines being an "African" in explicitly continent-wide and multiracial terms, and rejects all pretensions to victimhood.<ref>{{cite book|editor=Paul Smethurst|editor2=Julia Kuehn|title=New Directions in Travel Writing Studies|date=2015|publisher=Springer|isbn=1137457252|page=343|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=GZJMCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT342#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=24 August 2016}}</ref>
As [[Achille Mbembe]] and Sarah Nuttall write, "In an attempt to overturn predominant readings of Africa, we need to identify sites within the continent...not usually dwelt upon in research and public discourse, that defamiliarize commonplace readings of Africa." <ref name="Writing the World from an African Metropolis. Public Culture. vol 16,3 2004">[http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/pc/summary/v016/16.3mbembe01.html].</ref> These sites include fields like fashion, visual art, music and spiritual concerns.
The term was popularized in 2005 by a widely disseminated essay, "Bye-Bye, Babar (Or: What is an Afropolitan?)" by the author [[Taiye Selasi]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/02/17/world/africa/who-are-afropolitans/index.html | work=CNN | title=Young, urban and culturally savvy, meet the Afropolitans | date=17 February 2012}}</ref> Originally published in March 2005 in the Africa Issue of ''the LIP Magazine'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thelip.robertsharp.co.uk/?p=76 |title= Bye-Bye Barbar|publisher=''the LIP Magazine'' |date=3 March 2005}}</ref> the essay defines an Afropolitan identity, sensibility and experience. The critiques of the Afropolitan, as portrayed by Selasi in Bye-Bye, Babar, condemn its elitism and class biased approach. Susanne Gehrmann states that Selasi’s Afropolitan “is addicted to urban hip life” and “international careers.”<ref>Gehrmann, Susanne. "[http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/13696815.2015.1112770?scroll=top&needAccess=true Cosmopolitanism With African Roots. Afropolitanism's Ambivalent Mobilities]". Journal of African Cultural Studies 28.1 (2015): 61-72. Web.</ref> However, the essay is important in discussing where emigrantes of Africa fit into the spectrum of African. Knudsen and Rahbek suggest that Bye-Bye, Babar “is an integral part [in the] ongoing conversation about the relationship between identity and individuality” in the way that it “speaks to the individual” who may feel alone in the sense that they do not have “labels or identities” to understand their positioning in the world.<ref>Knudsen, Eva Rask, and Ulla Rahbek. In Search of the Afropolitan: Encounters, Conversations and Contemporary Diasporic African Literature. Lanham: Rowman & Littlefield International, 2016. Print.</ref> In 2006 the essay was republished by the Michael Stevenson Gallery in [[Cape Town]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clarkesbooks.co.za/artbooks/browse/41 |title=Clarke's Books |publisher=Clarkesbooks.co.za |accessdate=12 November 2011}}</ref> and in 2007 by ''The Nation'' in [[Nairobi]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Tuakli-Wosornu |first=Taiye |url=http://afrikanisation.blogspot.com/2007/09/africa-insight-new-africans-called.html |title=Africa Insight – the New Africans Called Afropolitans |publisher=''The Nation'' (Nairobi), reposted in Afrikanisation.blogspot.com |date=4 September 2007 |accessdate=}}</ref> whereupon it went viral. Several communities, artists, and publications now use the label, most notably The Afropolitan Network,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://afropolitans.typepad.com/ |title=The Afropolitan Network::: |publisher=Afropolitans.typepad.com |accessdate=12 November 2011}}</ref> The Afropolitan Experience,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theafropolitanexperience.com/ |title=The Afropolitan Experience |publisher=The Afropolitan Experience |date=7 November 2011 |accessdate=12 November 2011}}</ref> The Afropolitan Legacy Theatre,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afropolitanlegacy.com/ |title=Afropolitan Legacy Theatre |publisher=Afropolitanlegacy.com |accessdate=12 November 2011}}</ref> The Afropolitan Collection,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theafropolitancollection.com/campaign.html |title=By Eniola David |publisher=The Afropolitan Collection |accessdate=12 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325223859/http://www.theafropolitancollection.com/campaign.html |archivedate=25 March 2012 }}</ref> and South Africa's ''The Afropolitan Magazine''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afropolitan.co.za/ |title=The Afropolitan Magazine |publisher=Contact Media & Communications}}</ref> In June 2011 The [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] hosted "Friday Late: Afropolitans"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/f/afropolitans-24-june-2011/ |title=Friday Late, June: Afropolitans – Victoria and Albert Museum |publisher=Vam.ac.uk |accessdate=12 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111106223844/http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/f/afropolitans-24-june-2011/ |archivedate=6 November 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> in London. In September 2011 the Houston Museum of African American Culture convened the symposium "Africans in America: The New Beat of Afropolitans,” featuring author [[Teju Cole]], musician [[Derrick Ashong]] and artist [[Wangechi Mutu]] alongside Selasi.<ref>[http://www.hmaac.org/afropolitans.html "Africans in America - The New Beat of Afropolitans”, HMAAC: "This symposium marks the rise of a new cultural influence, brought to America and the world by a wave of fascinating young and creative cosmopolitan African immigrants, so called 'Afropolitans'."]</ref>
Ashong released an online album with the group Soulfège in 2011, titled "AFropolitan."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://derrickashong.com/music/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130903102051/http://derrickashong.com/music/ |archivedate=3 September 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> [[Blitz the Ambassador]] proposed in 2013 to release the CD "Afropolitan Dreams".<ref>"Blitz the Ambassador’s Afropolitan Dreams Block Party" http://afrofusionlounge.wordpress.com/2013/05/07/blitz-the-ambassadors-afropolitan-dreams-block-party/</ref> [[Ade Bantu]] is the co-creator of the monthly concert series [[Afropolitan Vibes]] which holds at Freedom Park Lagos, Nigeria.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/29/west-africa-afrobeat-uprising-musicians-afropop-big-band-political-spirit.</ref>
==See also== *[[Afrophile]] *[[Afrophilia]] *[[Afrophilya]]

{{italic title}} '''''Alefba''''' ({{lang-fa|'''الف‌ با'''}}) is a Persian-language literary magazine with two periods of publication, one in [[Iran]] before the 1979 revolution and another thereafter in [[France]]. [[Gholamhoseyn Sa'edi]] was the editor of both versions. In Iran the publisher was Amir Kabir Publishers, while in France the publisher was the Association of Iranian Writers in Exile.
==Tehran== Several Iranian literary magazines emerged in 1960s and 1970s as a result of new authors and increased literary production in the country.<ref>Hillmann, Michael. "Persian Prose Fiction: An Iranian Mirror and Conscience," in ''Persian Literature'', edited by Ehsan Yarshater (Albany, N.Y.: Bibliotheca Persica, 1988), p. 303.</ref> In 1973, Amir Kabir Publishers invested 25,000 [[Iranian toman|toman]] (about $3,500) in a new quarterly literary magazine, ''Alefba'', and selected Gholamhoseyn Sa'edi to be the editor.<ref name=pll>{{cite web|title=Persian Language & Literature|url=http://www.iranchamber.com/literature/gsaedi/gholamhossein_saedi.php|work=Iran Chamber|accessdate=17 June 2015}}</ref> Aside from the editorial labor, Sa'edi was responsible for its choosing its title, as well as penning the calligraphy decorating the cover. ''Alefba'' quickly gained status as one of Iran's top literary journals and famous Iranian intellectuals, such as [[Simin Daneshvar]], had their works published in it.<ref>Milani, Abbas. ''Eminent Persians: The Men and Women Who Made Modern Iran, 1941-1979'', Volume Two (Syracuse, N.Y.: Syracuse University Press, 2008), p. 881.</ref> Nevertheless Sa'edi frequently selected works of previously unpublished writers or writers he knew personally to be published, and esteemed the political independence of the magazine, which featured writers with different worldviews.<ref>Stodte, Claudia. ''Iranische Literatur zwischen gesellschaftlichem Engagement und existentieller Welterfahrung: Das Werk Ġolām-Ḥoseyn Sā'edis'', Europäische Hochschulschriften, Series XXVII, Vol. 72 (Frankfurt am Maine: Peter Lang, 2000), p. 84.</ref> In 1974, Sa'edi was arrested by [[SAVAK]], the late shah's secret police. He edited first six issues of the magazine between 1973 and 1976.<ref name=pll/> The last issue of ''Alefba'' (last issue in Tehran) was published in 1977.
==Paris== After the revolution, in 1982, Gholamhoseyn Sa'edi fled to France. Within months of his exile, together with the Association of Iranian Writers in Exile, Sa'edi began to publish a new version of ''Alefba'' in Paris. He continued to edit the magazine until his untimely death in 1985. The final 1986 issue is a collection of Sa'edi's previously unpublished works. Sa'edi wrote that the goal of ''Alefba'' was "to keep alive the Iranian art and culture which the Islamic Republic oppresses."<ref>Sa'edi, Gholamhoseyn. "Sharh-e Ahval," ''Alefba'' (Paris, 1986), no. 7, p. 5.</ref> In addition to publishing works of numerous other Iranians in exile, ''Alefba'' was the sole literary venue in which Sa'edi published his own works in exile.

'''Amoebaean singing''' is a type of [[singing]] competition originating in [[Ancient Greece]]. In it, a first party sings according to a topic and verse structure of their choosing. A second singer then responds with the same verse structure and on a related topic. This repeats until one side concedes or a third party can determine the winner. ==History== The form is believed to have been used by Greek [[shepherd]]s to entertain themselves. Later, it would evolve into a judged competition, consisting of multiple rounds of singing between competitors. Competitors would be judged more favorably if they could continue a theme through multiple rounds.{{cite journal|title=Oral Tradition|author=Pearce, J. B.|pages=63–64|volume=8|issue=1|url=http://journal.oraltradition.org/issues/8i/pearce|date=March 1993|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]}} The poet [[Theocritus]] relied heavily on Amoebaean singing, with it becoming his and his successors' "hallmark", according to [[David M. Halperin]]. ==Usage== Amoebaean singing can be seen in Theocritus' ''[[Idyll]] 5: The Goatherd and the Shepherd'', in an exchange between the [[goatherd]] Comatas and the [[shepherd]] Lacon.{{cite web|url=http://www.theoi.com/Text/TheocritusIdylls2.html#5|title=THEOCRITUS, IDYLLS 5-11|publisher=Theoi|accessdate=2009-10-26| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091106120935/http://www.theoi.com/Text/TheocritusIdylls2.html| archivedate= 6 November 2009 | deadurl= no}}
'''Comatas'''
''The Muses bear me greater love than Daphnis ere did see;''
''And well they may, fort’other day they had two goats for me.'' '''Lacon'''
''But Apollo loves me all as well, and an offering too have I,''
''A fine fat ram a-batt’ning; for Apollo’s feast draws nigh.''
==Further reading== * ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20120711033233/http://journal.oraltradition.org/files/articles/8i/4_pearce.pdf Theocritus and Oral Tradition] by James B. Pearce'' hosted by [[Google]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Amoebaean Singing}} [[Category:Ancient Greek music]] [[Category:Singing competitions]] {{music-stub}}

[[File:Battistero di San Giovanni Ascoli Piceno.jpg|thumb|Ascoli Piceno Baptistery]] The '''Ascoli Piceno Baptistery''' (Italian: ''Il battistero di San Giovanni di [[Ascoli Piceno]]''), also known as the [[baptistery]] of Saint John, is a religious building found on the eastern end of the [[piazza Arringo]] at the center of Ascoli Piceno and sitting next to and just north of the [[Ascoli Piceno Cathedral|cathedral dedicated to St. Emygdius]], the city's [[patron saint]].
The structure, simple and austere in its architectural form, perfectly represents the Romanesque style in Ascoli, and, being ranked among the best examples of Italian works of art, is included in the list of Italian [[national monument]]s <small>(r.d. n.7033 del 20/07/1890)</small>.
== History == The beginning of the baptistery's construction is difficult to date accurately, but archeological finds from 1828 and other excavations between 1870-1880 suggest that the interior of the structure was a pagan temple on Ascoli's forum which may have been dedicated to [[Hercules]].
According to Giambattista Carducci, the temple was used as a baptistery already by the 6th century. He also notes that its octagonal form is like the baptistery of [[Florence Baptistery|Saint John in Florence]], of the [[Arian Baptistery|Arian baptistery]] of [[Ravenna]], and of the [[Lateran Baptistery|Lateran baptistery i]]<nowiki/>n [[Rome]] built by [[Constantine the Great|Constantine]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Carducci|first1=Giambattista|title=Su le memorie e i monumenti di Ascoli nel Piceno|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=PBI5AAAAcAAJ|website=googlebooks|accessdate=19 November 2016|pages=88–89|date=1855}}</ref>
The baptistery's first restoration came prior to the 9th century, with interventions following in the 10th and 11th centuries as shown in the triangular decorations and the framing of the principal entrance. Most recently, the interior of the baptistery was restored in 2006.
== Architecture == The baptistery is constructed of large, square blocks of travertine, some of which were taken from earlier structures. Visible at the base of the eastern side are the remains of a Roman wall. It is a freestanding structure with a massive, square base containing entrances on two sides. The ''tiburio'' (the upper part of the structure designed to shape and protect the cupola within) is octagonal in shape, decorated with four small windows, and crowned with a square lantern, also containing windows to allow light inside. Each side of the ''tiburio'' is decorated with a [[blind arcade]] containing three round arches, with exception of the east facing side which contains a pair of arcades with only two arches each. All of these arcades were added during the 12th century.
{{CSS image crop |Image = Battistero di San Giovanni Ascoli Piceno.jpg |bSize = 950 |cWidth = 225 |cHeight = 325 |oTop = 510 |oLeft = 380 |Description = Main entrance of the Baptistery |350px}} The original monument had three entrances symbolizing the [[Trinity|Holy Trinity]] as well as [[Churches Militant, Penitent, and Triumphant|the Three Churches]]: ''the church militant'', composed of all the baptized faithful to [[Jesus|Christ]] and the [[Pope]]; ''the church penitent'', which includes all the souls in [[purgatory]] that are being prepared for heaven; and ''the church triumphant'', comprising the [[saint]]s and [[angel]]s. Today the baptistery has two entrances. The main entrance, found on [[piazza Arringo]], is flanked by two recessed rectangular forms, and the architrave above is decorated with three recessed triangles, one large triangle in the center which is marked by a wide horizontal slit, and two small ones on the sides. The other entrance faces the cathedral door known as the ''La porta della Musa'', and contains stone work from various periods, including Romanesque capitals and an bas-relief architrave that contains a knotted cord (a type of decoration that was very diffuse around the year 1000).
The interior of the baptistery has an irregular, octagonal shape, typically Roman, with [[Niche (architecture)|niches]] that correspond to the angles of the square base. The octagonal walls measure about 5,5 [[Metre|meters]] each; the dimensions of the interiore are 9,14 x 9 meters. Inside at the center of the floor, directly below the [[oculus]] of the [[Dome|cupola]], is a slightly raised circular pool, dated to the 5th or 6th century but rediscovered only in 1839, that was used by Christians for baptism by immersion. This unique spot was used for the baptism of both men and women who were assisted, respectively, by [[deacon]]s and [[deaconess]]es. On the right side is a [[baptismal font]] from the 14th or 15th century, set on top of a twisted column. On the altar is a painting of the ''Baptism of Christ'', a 16th-century oil on canvas, attributed to Venceslao Corrigioli di Reggio.
== Symbolism == The historian Mario Sabatucci has attributed a symbolic reading to the form of Ascoli's baptistery according to Christian doctrine. According to his interpretation, the square base represents the earth and its four elements (air, earth, fire, and water), the four points of the compass, the four seasons, and the four periods of a human life-span. The octagonal ''tiburio'' calls to mind baptism as described by St. Peter in his first letter: <small>(3,20-21)</small> ''« while God patiently waited to receive them, in Noah's time when the ark was being built. In it only a few, that is eight souls, were saved through water. It is the baptism corresponding to this water which saves you now ... »''<ref>{{cite web|title=The first letter of Peter|url=http://www.catholic.org/bible/book.php?id=67&bible_chapter=3|website=Catholic Online|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref> The round cupola, like a circle or a sphere, represents eternity and paradise.{{Citation needed|date=November 2016}}
== Images == <gallery> File:Battistero AP ingresso 2.jpg|Architrave with bas-rilief and traces of knotted cord File:Battistero AP monofora sopra l'ingrresso di Piazza Arringo.jpg|Single window above the entrance facing the piazza Arringo </gallery>
== Bibliography == * Giambattista Carducci, ''Su le memorie e i monumenti di Ascoli nel Piceno'', Fermo, S. Del Monte, 1853, pp. 88–91; * Antonio Rodilossi, Ascoli Piceno città d'arte, "Stampa & Stampa" Gruppo Euroarte Gattei, Grafiche STIG, Modena, 1983, p. 73;
